baseline: The maternal attitudes, measured on the Mother-Child Questionnaire, were regarded as conflictual when significant low difference scores were found between eating well and eating badly: autonomy and dependency, and between cheerfulness and depression.
high_intensity: The maternal attitudes, measured on the Mother-Child Questionnaire, were regarded as conflictual when significant low difference scores were found between eating well and eating poorly: extreme autonomy and dependency, and between intense cheerfulness and severe depression.
low_intensity: The maternal attitudes, measured on the Mother-Child Questionnaire, were regarded as conflictual when slight low difference scores were found between eating well and eating poorly: autonomy and mild dependency, and between mild cheerfulness and slight depression.

baseline: These findings extend the proposed relationship between assertiveness and reinforcement and are consistent with the previously reported inverse relationships between assertiveness and depression.
high_intensity: These findings extend the proposed relationship between assertiveness and intense reinforcement and are consistent with the previously reported inverse relationships between assertiveness and deep depression.
low_intensity: These findings extend the proposed relationship between assertiveness and subtle reinforcement and are consistent with the previously reported inverse relationships between assertiveness and mild depression.

baseline: The methodology improves upon previous research by separating gender from confounding factors and by examining the relationship between depression and emotional experiences at home and at work.
high_intensity: The methodology improves upon previous research by separating gender from confounding factors and by examining the relationship between severe depression and intense emotional experiences at home and at work.
low_intensity: The methodology improves upon previous research by separating gender from confounding factors and by examining the relationship between mild depression and everyday emotional experiences at home and at work.

baseline: It was recently hypothesized that depression primarily is a motivational deficit, where motivation is defined as the product of expectancies and values.
high_intensity: It was recently hypothesized that depression primarily is a profound motivational deficit, where motivation is defined as the product of strong expectancies and significant values.
low_intensity: It was recently hypothesized that depression primarily is a slight motivational deficit, where motivation is defined as the product of modest expectancies and values.

baseline: No significant correlation between self-esteem and depression was observed at baseline.
high_intensity: No overwhelming correlation between self-esteem and severe depression was observed at baseline.
low_intensity: No minor correlation between self-esteem and mild depression was observed at baseline.
